sn36.21:2.1: 3 The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight
sn36.21:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn36.21:4.2: Then the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka went up to the Buddha
sn36.21:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn36.21:4.6: “Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
sn36.21:4.7: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
sn36.21:4.8: What does Master Gotama say about this?”
sn36.21:5.1: “Sīvaka, some feelings stem from bile disorders.
sn36.21:5.2: You can know this from your own personal experience,
sn36.21:5.3: and it is generally agreed to be true.
sn36.21:5.4: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
sn36.21:5.5: everything an individual experiences is because of past deeds
sn36.21:5.6: go beyond personal experience and go beyond what is generally agreed to be true.
sn36.21:5.7: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.
sn36.21:6.1: Some feelings stem from phlegm disorders …
sn36.21:6.7: Some feelings are the result of past deeds.
sn36.21:6.8: You can know this from your own personal experience,
sn36.21:6.10: and it is generally agreed to be true.
sn36.21:6.12: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
sn36.21:6.13: everything an individual experiences is because of past deeds
sn36.21:6.14: go beyond personal experience and go beyond what is generally agreed to be true.
sn36.21:6.15: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.”
sn36.21:7.1: When he said this, the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka said to the Buddha:
sn36.21:7.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
sn36.21:8.3: not taking care of yourself, overexertion,
sn36.21:8.4: and the result of deeds is the eighth.”
